text: if you were shopping for a new monitor a
few years ago the general rule was that
gamers would buy tn panels for their
higher refresh rates and fast pixel
response times while creative types
would get ips type panels for their
accurate colors and wide viewing angles
fast forward to today and ips refresh
rates have climbed from 75 to 110 and
even 144 hertz and now
lg is claiming to have also closed the
pixel response time gap with the 27
144hz ips monitor with an advertised one
millisecond pixel response time by
developing a panel with a new
high-speed liquid crystal layer that
promises tn levels of speed if they
pulled that off it's an industry first
and it's a huge deal but is it marvelous
or is it marketing
[Music]
the main effect of pixel response time
is the motion blur or the trail behind
moving objects and in order to show you
guys exactly what the motion blur is
like on this monitor we turned to
blurbuster's excellent guide on how to
build your own inexpensive pursuit
camera the idea is to put a camera on a
slider and then try to move it at
exactly the same speed as the objects on
screen
that way you can capture only the
aspects of motion blur that are caused
by the display and not those that are
caused by the image persistence of the
human eye sliding the camera at the
right speed takes a few tries but they
built in this easy way to tell if you
did it right if these lines slant
backwards you were too slow forwards
means you were too fast and if they
align vertically then you deserve a high
so
here's our results
and
admittedly the image is still not
crystal clear but maybe we just need
some context for this let's compare with
a couple of other monitors then starting
with another ultra gear 120hz gaming
monitor from lg that's advertised as
having a more typical ips response time
of 5 milliseconds so
there's no real difference in the amount
of detail that we can see in our ufo but
where there is a difference is in the
amount of ghosting visible on the
trailing edge of the ship as the pixels
struggle to switch colors quickly enough
now we also compared the 27 gl850 to a
one millisecond tn panel the asus pg258q
and again we get a similar level of
detail between the two
but interestingly the asus has a
different visual artifact on the
trailing edge called corona or inverse
ghosting this particular artifact is the
result of pixel overdrive a technique
that uses higher voltages to make the
pixels switch colors faster now the goal
of overdrive is to reduce ghosting but
it often comes with a side effect called
overshoot where the pixel briefly
switches beyond the target color and
then has to come back causing this
bright inverse ghosting in the 27 gl850
settings which you navigate with the
nipple joystick still my favorite for
on-screen displays you can actually
adjust how aggressive the pixel
overdrive is the results we've shown you
so far were from tests that used the
fast setting when we crank it up to
faster we get coronas again just like
the tn and these look really bad in game
like i would never ever put this monitor
or for that matter pretty much any
monitor on
fastest because it makes it look way
worse with no real benefit that i can
see the good news is that to me the next
setting down feels fantastic already
like it's really snappy with barely any
overshoot artifacts but that made me
wonder why would lg include this faster
setting at all surely they must know as
well as i do that it just looks bad well
here's one theory back when this monitor
was announced at e3 2019 the community
was already wondering whether lg's one
millisecond claim was something that the
display could achieve reliably or
something it could only do under special
circumstances and with overdrive
absolutely cranked so we think that this
option is only here so that they could
put one millisecond on the box even if
no one ourselves or lg would actually
recommend using that setting but that's
not to say that i don't love this
monitor i think it's a great monitor and
not even just because of the response
times which do play really clean it also
has a 144hz native refresh rate very
decent color accuracy out of the box
thanks to lg's use of nanoceltec which
you can learn more about in this video
and it's got variable refresh rate in
the form of adaptive sync now some of
you might remember that this monitor was
advertised as having g-sync hardware in
it when it was first announced but as
you can plainly see the g suffix has
since been dropped from the product name
now the monitor still does have a g-sync
sticker on it because it received the
g-sync compatible label from nvidia so
you'll have variable refresh rate
regardless of which graphics team you
play for but you'll miss out on some of
the extras that would have come with a
g-sync hardware module and full
certification like an unlimited variable
refresh window and 165 hertz
overclocking which i guess brings us
perfectly then to the 27 gl850s
downsides the first is the lack of hdr
now
technically speaking this monitor does
support hdr in that it can accept an
hdr10 input source and you can flip hdr
on in windows however the peak
brightness is just 350 nits so it
doesn't even qualify for vasa's lowly
display hdr 400 certification similarly
it doesn't have any local dimming to
deepen the dark parts of the scene now
honestly speaking i'm not
that bothered because hdr on pc still
has some software issues and even
premium full array local dimming hdr
monitors like the one i have at home can
still suffer from halos and poor viewing
angles due to the chunky dimming zones
moving to the outside the i o is also
just okay one displayport 1.4 two hdmi
2.0 ports and a small hub with two usb
3s and a spot for your microphone so
it's fine but i'd be a lot more jazzed
if there was a usbc to enable a single
cable connection to my laptop finally
there's the stand the height adjust
feels really smooth it's got tilt and
even the less common pivot but curiously
it doesn't swivel i mean this is not a

would sit right in front of your monitor
so it'll be perfectly aligned and
